McCarron, who is 41 years old and lives at 311 East Seventy-fourth Street, will plead tomorrow or Monday before Judge John J. Freschi of General Sessions.

A special bulletin dealing with loans to retailers by the Federal Reserve Banks was issued yesterday by the controllers' congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association. Pointing out that it is now possible for stores to obtain financial assistance on a three-to-five-year basis, the bulletin outlines three plans of procedure under which the loans may be secured.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- Rules on continuation or extension of unlisted trading as given out today by the Securities and Exchange Commission were as follows:

Albert V. Moore, president of the American Scantic Line, returning yesterday on the Scanpenn from a trip to Scandinavian and Baltic countries, was enthusiastic about conditions there and optimistic over the outlook for trade between them and the United States.
The White Sox, it seems, overstayed their welcome in this town by exactly twenty-four hours.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 29 (AP). -- The Pirates, aided by the brilliant pitching of the veteran Waite Hoyt, shut out the Braves, 7 to 0, in the second game of a double-header today after Boston had crushed Pittsburgh, 11 to 0, in the opener.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 29. -- Scamp, of the neighboring Pequot Yacht Club, with Johannes Schiott at the tiller, finished first in the second of three races for the Atlantic class championship on Long Island Sound today, to take the lead in the series by a one-point margin.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- On the eve of his departure for New York to spend the week-end with President Roosevelt at Hyde Park, Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator, repeated today his previously expressed conviction that it is not the business of the government either to underwrite or to break strikes.

FANOE, Denmark, Aug. 29. -- Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller sent a special emissary by plane today from Berlin to the meeting of the Universal Christian Council for Life and Work to make a final plea against the growing conviction among the church leaders gathered here that the present swastika regime in the established German Protestant Church is un-Christian.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- Schools, homes, churches and the criminal courts were criticized here today by Dr. Walter N. Thayer Jr., State Commissioner of Correction, as contributing unwittingly to the high crime rate in New York. Dr. Thayer spoke at the annual convention of the National Identification Association, an organization of police officials.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 29. -- The Hampton Players gave "Good Morning," a comedy by John Gibbs, at the John Drew Memorial Theatre here tonight before an audience which included Mrs. William Carter Dickerman, Mr. and Mrs. Jack Van Ryder, Mrs. C.L. Dixon, Miss Jessie Oliver, George H. Keim, Mrs. Thomas Jefferson Mumford and Mrs. Lorenzo E. Woodhouse.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Aug. 29. -- Ridden by her owner, Miss Charlotte Ives Montgomery of Villanova, Pa., the handsome chestnut mare Lady Godiva won the Corinthian Class competitions, for the Governor A. Harry Moore Challenge Trophy today, the feature horse show event at the annual Flemington Agricultural Fair.

With reference to the letter from Representative Wright Patman appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 25, wherein he objects to the recommendation of the American Veterans Association that an honor roll be publicly displayed containing the names of all veterans drawing pensions or other compensation as the result of war service, I desire to make the following observations:

CHICAGO, Aug. 29. -- The Giants are riding the rails back home tonight via Flint, Mich., exactly where they were when they left three weeks ago -- four and one-half games in front in the torrid struggle for the National League pennant.

SIMLA, India, Aug. 29. -- "The curtain has fallen, I hope finally, on the civil disobedience movement," said the Earl of Willingdon, the Viceroy, today in a speech at the final session of the Indian Central Legislature.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29. -- Medical science today had its first official story of the birth and infancy of quintuplets, a dramatic but simple account by the country doctor who was both obstetrician and parish priest to the five daughters of Mrs. Elzire Dionne on their birth morn last May 28.

All the city's public beaches, including Coney Island, which are on the approved list of the Health Department, are safe for bathing, a special committee of Fellows of the New York Academy of Medicine asserted in a report made public yesterday by Mayor LaGuardia.

Preparations to cope with the threatened strike of 10,000 truck drivers were made last night by members of the Merchant Truckmen's Bureau of New York at a meeting in the bureau headquarters, 240 West Fourteenth Street.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 29. -- A sweeping program aimed at reform in procedure under criminal law to combat crime in the United States was adopted here today by the convention of the American Bar Association. For the first time in the association's history, an entire day was devoted to the crime problem.

The President has made almost superhuman efforts to correct these conditions and has succeeded so well that the outlook for the future has perceptibly brightened, but the President himself has said that his projects are necessarily experimental and that if one failed to produce results he would try another.
The selling and leasing of properties for modernizing featured realty activity in Manhattan yesterday.

Even if the names of George Abbott and Philip Dunning were not attached to "Kill That Story," hardy students of the drama would know from what atelier the new comedy derives. In this instance Mr. Abbott is the director; Mr. Dunning and Harry Madden are the authors.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- Mrs. Anne Morrow Lindbergh, temporarily turned author, has undertaken in gay paragraphs to humanize her famous husband.

BERLIN, Aug. 29. -- Amazement at what he termed the lack of protection of human civil rights in the German courts was expressed today by William O. Thompson, Chicago and New York lawyer, who has been in Germany studying the juristic situation and trying to visit the Nazi prison camps.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- The naval high command reacted unfavorably today to the British suggestion that future battleships be limited to 32,000 tons displacement instead of the maximum limit of 35,000 tons fixed by the Treaty of Washington.

The estate of George E. Riegel, a resident of Maine, who died on Jan. 11, 1933, was appraised yesterday at $404,212 gross and $342,594 net, of which $310,468 was in securities. The most valuable holding was 5,529 shares of the Riegel Paper Corporation, worth $193,515.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 29. -- More than 150 women contributed $1,750 to the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies at a luncheon and garden party held today on the estate of Mrs. Irving Gelder of Kings Point. The event was sponsored by the North Shore group of the women's division of the federation.

Fortunate is the angler who can take a holiday in these waning weeks of the Summer at a favorite retreat in the hills. Days are cool, streams and lakes inviting. And if he has an eye for beauty, the opportunity of observing the changes in nature's raiment as Autumn creeps up is an added delight.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- President Roosevelt regards the $2,800,000,000 profit in gold accruing to the Treasury from devaluation of the dollar as a nest egg to be disposed of only in the indefinite future.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29. -- The Dodgers' farewell performance of 1934 in St. Louis brought great entertainment today to a ladies' day gathering of more than 7,000 and several acute pains to Manager Casey Stengel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- Events moved rapidly today toward the first general textile strike in American labor history. The strike order will be effective not later than Saturday. The call will go to 500,000 cotton textile workers and 300,000 in related industries, such as rayon, silk, hosiery and embroidery.

As a result of the wage increase in sweater mills here following settlement of the recent strike, the knitted outerwear industry was yesterday reported to be seeking an increase in the price ranges of mills selling to the retail trade.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 29 (AP). -- Theodore G. Bilbo, the "stormy petrel" of Mississippi politics, won his way into a run-off Senatorial contest with Senator Hubert D. Stephens in yesterday's Democratic primary.

Dorothy Thompson, American newspaper correspondent and wife of Sinclair Lewis, who was recently expelled from Germany by the Hitler government, attributed yesterday a "program of mystification" to the German Propaganda Ministry.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 29. -- Miss Eleanor Swayne gave a luncheon today at Algoma, her home in the Shinnecock Hills, for Mrs. Edwin Gould of Highwood, Oyster Bay, who is visiting her.

VIENNA, Aug. 29. -- Official Austria is deeply disappointed and indignant over the "excessive" hospitality Yugoslavia is extending to the 2,000 Austrian Nazi exiles who fled to Yugoslavia after the recent Nazi putsch.

BUFFALO, Aug. 29. -- Mayor LaGuardia asked leaders of the State Federation of Labor here tonight to see that any employer moving his business out of New York paid his new employes the same wages and provided the same working conditions as he did in New York.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 29. -- Documentary evidence shows that the executive committee of the Third International in Moscow has ordered the Communist party in this country to "smear the NRA," the Rev. Edmund A. Walsh said here today.
All sections of the money market were quiet in tone and unchanged in quotations. Except for replacements, there was virtually no demand for new accommodation.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- Making a show of his field over a heavy track, William Woodward's Vicar today scored his second stake victory of the week when he was first in the Huron Handicap of a mile and three-sixteenths. At the end of the route, which was finished in 2:02, the son of Flying Ebony and Valkyr was five lengths to the good and coasting.
LONDON, Aug. 30 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- An inquiry on the question whether banks are extending credit to the smaller industries on as generous a scale as economic conditions warrant will be made in the Chicago Federal Reserve District, Secretary Morgenthau said today.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low figure for the year.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- The NRA was asked today by New York Harbor carriers to stop the "chiseling on the workers' side, as well as on the employers' side."

SALZBURG, Aug. 30. -- Although the Salzburg festival has several days to run, there are many who regarded tonight's third and last Toscanini concert as its real close, as it was indeed the crown and culmination of a month of magnificent music-making.

WILDWOOD, N.J., Aug. 30. -- The political and business troubles of Assemblyman William C Hunt were multiplied today when he discovered that a safe in his office had been blown open during the night and records pertaining to his legislative and financial affairs had been stolen.

WILLIAMS GROVE, Pa., Aug. 30. -- At a rally attended by 40,000 farmers marking the formal beginning of the Republican State campaign, senator David A. Reed demanded today that President Roosevelt "quit tampering with the currency and give the country sound money."

Several American steamship operators are considering a return to the use of coal as a result of the price of fuel oil, R.J. Baker, president of the American Steamship Owners Association, declared yesterday. Mr. Baker made this statement in a protest filed with the Petroleum Administrative Board against the rapidly mounting cost of oil, which, he declared, had risen to more than 100 per cent above the 1932 price.

Posing as a prospective customer, a soft-spoken, well-dressed young woman walked into a Brooklyn beauty parlor yesterday morning and robbed the proprietor of $46 after producing a pistol and remarking "Do as you are told or I'll blow your brains out."

BAD EILSEN, Germany, Aug. 30. -- The conference of agrarian economists meeting here was treated today to diametrically opposed explanations of the place of money in the modern world by Professor George F. Warren of Cornell University, a United States Government adviser, and Professor Schumacker of Berlin.
ATLANTA, Aug. 30 (AP). -- George L. Googe, Southern representative of the American Federation of Labor, issued today the following statement:

A statement was published recently that the deputy tax commissioners had lowered the assessed values of Manhattan by $900,000,000. If this decrease were made proportionately in the other boroughs it would mean a lowered assessment of $1,200,000,000.

Many years ago my grandfather left to my cousin and me some unfortunate Montana land about which I know nothing beyond the point of ownership. Recently my son-in-law, a lawyer, sent me a check for $4.04, payable jointly to my cousin and me by the United States Government, with the comment, "The government is sending you the enclosed check because somebody did not raise wheat somewhere."
RENO, Nev., Aug. 30. -- Three families in New York and New Jersey were involved in divorce actions here today.

Coincident with the closing of the trout season in New York today, anglers of New Jersey are looking forward with eagerness to the inauguration in their State tomorrow of the second period of trout fishing this year. The first season in New Jersey lasted from April 15 to July 15.

In THE TIMES editorial "Relief for Strikers" this conclusion appears. "If the rule were established that the government would feed and lodge every man out of work, even if plenty of work were waiting for him on conditions, the result would be a general laying down of tools until the government, too, would also lay its down and make a plea in bankruptcy."

In sustaining on Wednesday an indictment under the Recovery Act, a Federal judge held that it was "an emer "gency measure and represents a "change in social theory." Replying to the argument that the power of Congress to regulate interstate commerce does not imply power to regulate the conduct of those engaged in it, Judge CAMPBELL said: "With the choice of "means we have no concern; that rests "with Congress."

Sales of department stores in the New York metropolitan area which reported to the Federal Reserve Bank showed an increase of about 1 per cent over the 1933 period during the first half of August, according to the Sept. 1 review of credit and business conditions by the Federal Reserve Agent at New York.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- A recommendation by President Roosevelt for uniform automobile safety laws "with strict and impartial enforcement" was made public today by Secretary Roper.

Eight former officers and directors of the defunct Pelham National Bank of Pelham, N.Y., were named in three indictments returned yesterday by the Federal grand jury which accused them of misapplying and abstracting funds of the bank and of making false reports to the Controller of the Currency.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 30. -- The donkey class promises to be a feature at the horse show being sponsored by Mrs. Henry D. Phelps and her sister, Mrs. Earl E.T. Smith, for the benefit of the Newport Family Welfare on Sept. 7 and 8. Mrs. Snowden A. Fahnestock, Mrs. Moses Taylor, Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt and Mrs. Michael M. Van Beuren have made entries.

Wall Street's attitude toward the share market yesterday was one of detachment. Stocks worked lower in quiet trading, but the fluctuations were regarded a somewhat pointless since there were no speculative impulses of consequence at work in the market.

The Blue combination, which has been together as a team during the last several test matches among candidates for the East team, which will play the West in the championship polo series, opening at the Meadow Brook Club on Sept. 8, has been broken up by the selection committee, it was learned yesterday.
ARCOLA, N.J., Aug. 30. -- Sidney W. Noyes Jr., young Ardsley golfer, won the medal in the qualifying round of the annual Arcola invitation tournament today with a score of 74, three strokes over par.

AUGUSTA, Me., Aug. 30. -- Setting what is believed to be a precedent in Maine politics, Frank W. Carlton of Woolwich, Executive Councilor, prominent Republican and twice unsuccessful candidate for the nomination for Governor, declared tonight he would support the Democratic Governor, Louis J. Brann, for re-election Sept. 10.

Yesterday was the coolest day of the month and the coolest Aug. 30 in New York's history. The temperature dropped to 52 at 6:30 A.M., bettering by 3 degrees the previous all-time low for the date, established in 1888. However, continued, fair weather is promised for today.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- The world's greatest doubles player proved today that it is a little bit premature to relegate him to the scrap heap as a figure-head in singles.

With the approach of the holiday week-end, traders in the various domestic speculative markets conducted their routine operations yesterday with a half-hearted spirit. The volume of business was small and the price movements were restricted to a greater extent than usual.

LONDON, Aug. 30. -- The famous Finnish four-masted barque Lawhill arrived at Gravesend today, after an adventurous 170-day voyage from Adelaide, Australia. The last sailing ship completing the grain race from Australia, the Lawhill reached port just 120 days after Captain Tomm had brought the Abraham Rydberg home -- the first of the windjammers to arrive.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 30. -- Sweeping and swift, with beauty and strength in her every line, Rainbow sailed around a thirty-mile triangle today in the seventh of the final America's Cup defense trials, defeating Yankee 2 minutes and 21 seconds.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 30 (AP). -- The Tigers stubbornly refused to be downed today and after tottering on the edge of defeat for six innings put on a late drive to beat the Indians, 6 to 1, in the series opener and maintain their five-game lead over the Yankees.

The pound sterling continued yesterday its swift depreciation against the dollar and the franc while those two currencies remained unchanged at a relationship which caused further gold to flow from this country to France.
Establishment of Summer camps in near-by State parks for underprivileged New York City school children is being considered by the State and city authorities, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Aug. 29, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,461,000,000, a decrease of $3,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of 194,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1983.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Aug. 30. -- Horses owned by Mrs. Charles F. Henry of Devon, Pa., scored impressive victories to win two of the four championships decided today as the annual two-day horse show was concluded at the Flemington Agricultural Fair.
The share of St. Joseph's Hospital of Far Rockaway from the benefit performance staged last week by the Atlantic Beach Club amounts to $5.22.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 30. -- Swedish-German transfer negotiations have resulted in a bilateral exchange clearing agreement based on the German export surplus to Sweden in 1933, amounting to 90,000,000 marks.

BERLIN, Aug. 30. -- Trading in the Boerse was wholly stagnant today. Reports that Minister of Economy Hjalmar Schacht would make a plea for a full debt moratorium in his speech at Bad Eilsen forced professionals to withdraw from the market or reduce their holdings until the foreign reaction had been ascertained.

Ray M. Gidney, hitherto deputy governor of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, has been appointed senior assistant Federal Reserve agent, it was announced yesterday by the Reserve Bank. Mr. Gidney will assist J. Herbert Case, Federal Reserve agent and chairman of the local Reserve Bank, in supervising the many new functions that have come under the Federal Reserve agent's office as a result of recent banking legislation.

AVON, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- A chestnut colt by Thunderation, out of Lassie, and owned by Thomas H. Clements of Avon, today was awarded the championship of all the foals which had won prizes at the first session of the twentieth annual Autumn show of the Genesee Valley Breeders Association. The exhibition was held at Avon Springs Park.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 30 -- H.H. Holbrook of Sorento, Ill., won the preliminary handicap trap-shoot today, defeating H.G. Trimmer of Detroit and W.L. Yeaman of Logan, Iowa, in a shoot-off after the three had tied at 96.

The first plan for reorganizing foreclosed realty under the provisions of an amendment to the Burchill law signed last Friday by Governor Lehman will be put into effect as the result of the sale at auction yesterday of the twenty-five-story office building at 2 Park Avenue.

A group of seven outstanding American track and field athletes, headed by Bill Bonthron, former Princeton middle-distance star, returned to the United States yesterday on the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland from an extensive competitive tour of Europe.

With a strong advance in sugar futures a feature of the day's activities, trading on the local commodity Exchanges yesterday brought weakness and uncertainty to all staples except coffee and rubber. Rubber, however, ended well under its opening levels.
Police Commissioner O'Ryan promoted twenty-four more sergeants to the rank of lieutenant yesterday, thus completing his quota of forty-eight. The others were promoted on Aug. 22.
Several extra dividends, as well as a resumption of payments and one initial disbursement, were announced yesterday.

In a suit charging monopoly of the nation's popular music, the Government of the United States sought yesterday break up all license-fee agreements made by the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers with radio broadcasting stations throughout the country.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Aug. 30. -- President Roosevelt's emergency measures not only preserved the American system of government and life, but also prevented a violent revolution James A. Farley, Postmaster General and chairman of the Democratic National Committee, declared tonight in an address at a dinner given in his honor by the Luzerne County Democratic Committee.

ALBANY, Aug. 30. -- The State Department of Education today announced the lists, by counties, of the names of those high school pupils who have won university scholarships. The holder of one of these scholarshps is entitled to $100 a year for the four years of his college course while attending any college in the State approved by the regents for this purpose.

Application has been made for the listing on the New York Stock Exchange of an additional amount of $2,000,000 fifteen-year secured 6 per cent sinking fund bonds, Series A, of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation. The bonds are issued under the same trust indenture as the $8,000,000 bonds listed on the Stock Exchange in June, but are due July 1, 1949, compared with a maturity date of June 1, 1949, for the $8,000,000 issue.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
The third link of the West Side elevated highway was opened yesterday with ceremonies at which Borough President Samuel Levy envisioned the overhead road as eventually encircling Manhattan Island.
STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 30. -- Isaac L. Merrill of Daytona, Fla., the medalist, today gained the semi-final round of the thirty-eighth annual men's invitation golf tournament here.
LONDON, Aug. 30. -- The road to membership in the League of Nations stretched straight and smooth before Soviet Russia tonight.

Alfred P. Sloan, president of the General Motors Corporation, returning yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa from a three weeks' vacation in the south of France, said that he approved of the principles of the American Liberty League.
MONTREAL, Que., Aug. 30. -- A membership in the Montreal Silver Exchange was reserved today for one of the largest firms dealing in silver in Shanghai, China.

RHINEBECK, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- President Roosevelt was an interested spectator at the final day of the Dutchess County horse show today, although his plans prevented him from staying to present the trophy which he and Mrs. Roosevelt offered for the best horse in the show.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- Rehabilitation of the West is a problem in which the East must share both the responsibility and the cost, President Roosevelt said today in an impromptu speech before about 1,000 of his neighbors. They were members of the Roosevelt Home Club who had gathered at his farm near here to greet him.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Increasing unemployment is wiping out earlier advances toward industrial recovery, and will create, if unchecked, "a worse problem than we had last year," William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared today. He demanded to know if the NRA intended to act or whether it intended to leave the problem to the National Relief Administration.

Officials of the New York Post-Graduate Medical School and Hospital of Columbia University, and of the Stuyvesant Square Hospital, better known as the New York Skin and Cancer Hospital, announced last night that an "affiliation" between the two institutions had been decided upon.

The constantly recurring topic of reviving the legitimate theatre on the road will be discussed by members of the Actors Equity Association at meeting to be held on Sept. 28, in the Hotel Astor. In addition, two proposed amendments, recommended by the Equity Council, will be considered.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- An exchange of ideas on the possibility of restricting the amount of merchant shipping on the seas, which may lead to an international conference on the subject, has been suggested by Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, in a memorandum to leading maritime powers, it was learned today.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange weakened yesterday under news of the impending textile strike and ended with loss as of 14 to 17 points. May contracts touched 13.35 cents, or within 7 points of the low marks of the month and 88 points under the high levels made after announcement of the government crop estimate three weeks age.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30. -- One of the greatest movements of gold in the history of the world started today.

With Germany's moratorium on her external debt service caused solely by transfer difficulties, the Institute of Internal Finances, conducted by the Investment Bankers Association in cooperation with New York University, in a survey of German finances made public yesterday, takes the Reich to task for the interpretation placed on its foreign exchange resources and foreign trade figures.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 30 (AP). -- Disregarding the efforts of the Republican State chairman, W. Kingsland Macy, to restrict the Fall campaign to State issues, Representative James W. Wadsworth, Old Guard leader, has announced that he would lead a drive to make the New Deal policies the main issue.

In the second of his promised series of reports, Mr. RICHBERG deals with the agricultural policies of the Administration. Their objectives have been an increase of farm purchasing power and an improvement of the agricultural credit system. Concerning the first point, he reports that "basic" farm commodities have now reached 95 per cent of their pre-war "parity."

CHICAGO, Aug. 30. -- While the grains on the Board of Trade fluctuated erratically in price today, they were firm in undertone, especially corn. Commission houses took the offerings on the dips on resting orders and scattered selling was readily absorbed.

BERLIN, Aug. 30. -- The publication by the Voelkischer Beobachter of two letters that the late President Paul von Hindenburg wrote in 1914 shows clearly that he regarded himself a few days before his appointment to command the army at Tannenberg as a wholly forgotten man.

BYRON, Minn., Aug. 30 (AP). -- Grabbing a shotgun that lay behind bullet-proof glass, a 44-year-old bank president today ignored a bandit's pistol and frustrated a hold-up of the State Bank of Byron by capturing two men.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30. -- The demand for hogs was less aggressive today here, and while early sales were at prices higher than those of yesterday, the finish was weak to 15 cents a hundredweight lower, with light kinds and packing sows regarded as off somewhat more on scattered sales.

" A Sleeping Clergyman," by James Bridie, has been selected by the Theatre Guild for its initial production this season. Rehearsals will begin on Sept. 10 under the direction of Philip Moeller and the play will open here about Oct. 15. It was shown last season in London.

KEANSBURG, N.J., Aug. 30. -A lottery ring operating on a $1,000,000 scale was revealed here today following the arrest yesterday of seven men and two women in a raid by Sheriff Howard Height and a large party of deputies. Department of Justice agents also stepped into the case last night.

Two three-story al@rtment houses are to replace the old New York I-Iospital at 5 to 23 West Fifteenth Street and 6 to 16 @Vest Sixteenth Street, near Fifth Avenue. The@ structures are to cost $!25,000 and! $150,000 respectively, making a total of $275,000.

Count and Countess de Revilla de Carmago and James D. Mooney, president of General Motors Export Company, are among the passengers sailing tonight for Channel ports on the Worth German Lloyd liner Europa.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 30. -- A series of vigorous attacks upon the New Deal during the first two days of its current convention resulted today in a decision by the American Bar Association to investigate the new Federal legislation developed under the Roosevelt program.

The Engineers Public Service Company reports consolidated gross earnings of $42,784,070 for the year ended July 31, 1934, compared with $42,145,507 in the preceding year, and net operating revenue of $17,827,285, against $19,323,964, a decline of $1,496,679.

DETROIT, Aug. 30. -- The Ford Motor Company's $12,750,000 steel plant expansion program, designed to make the company independent of all other manufacturers of steel, will begin immediately, according to an announcement today.

Army officers were still battling a "foreign foe" across reams of paper yesterday, while the nation was mustering its strength to combat the menace of an "invasion" by a Black coalition in New Jersey and Delaware.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 30. -The discovery of important buildings in three sections of the market place of ancient Corinth and of a temple as yet unidentified was announced today by Dr. Richard Stillwell, director of the American School of Classical Studies at Athens, which supported the excavations this Spring.

PARIS, Aug. 30. -- Three separate groups of enemy bombing planes succeeded in bombing Le Bourget in today's air manoeuvres despite the efforts of pursuit squadrons sent up to prevent the attack and the rapidity with which the alarm was given by radio as soon as the invaders were detected crossing the advance lines.

Brokers and renting agents were kept busy again yesterday signing up new tenants for apartment houses. The East Side, especially in the Fifth and Park Avenue sections, was the chief centre of activity, although buildings on the West Side added their share of names to their rosters. Some tenants renewed their leases.
A threat to harm President Roosevelt and kidnap three of his grandchildren was revealed here yesterday with the arrest of Benjamin Franklin Varn of Charleston, S.C.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Aug. 30. -- Making no comment today regarding the issues involved, Willard Dowell, executive secretary of the North Carolina Merchants Association, described the textile strike as a "severe blow."

A reopening of the trade agreement signed last Friday by the United States and Cuba will be sought from the Department of State today by domestic textile exporters in an effort to obtain higher preferential rates on American cotton goods, it was decided here yesterday by the foreign relations committee of the Textile Export Associations of the United States.

In January I suggested to State Senator Desmond that the solution of the mortgage problem would be the most important single duty of the Legislature which had just convened, and that in my judgment such a solution would be found in creating a mortgage authority.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Faced with the gravest strike threat that has confronted the Roosevelt administration in the last year, twelfth-hour conferences held tonight failed to make any substantial progress toward averting the textile walkout, scheduled to begin at 11:30 Saturday night.

BUFFALO, Aug. 30. -- Reorganization of the State's school system was advocated at the closing session of the State Federation of Labor convention today. The resolution deplored a "growing autocracy and inadequacy in education" and suggested that the younger generation be fostered in "a critical-minded outlook instead of a defeatist attitude."

EDGARTOWN, Mass, Aug. 30. -- For the third time in its history and the second time in succession, the Vineyard Haven Yacht Club won the Sears Cup when Skipper Frank Jewett Jr. and his crew of Theodore Robie and Lane Fuller finished second in the concluding race today.

PARIS, Aug. 30. -- The Ministries of Foreign Affairs and Finance are discussing Washington's notification to French brokerage houses that profits on speculation in Wall Street are taxable, it was learned today.

Despite the reduction in the number of buyers here, activity in the local wholesale apparel and accessory markets was well sustained during the week. Cool weather in many sections of the country has turned consumer interest rather early to Fall apparel, with the result that continued reorders have been found necessary to round out the light initial stocks in retailers' hands.

MOSCOW, Aug. 30. -- "Once upon a time" -- to be exact, it was Sept. 3, 1911 -- Nicholas II, Czar of All the Russias, visited the ancient little Ukrainian town of Korosten and "received bread and salt from his loyal subjects." as stated upon the pedestal of a statue erected to him in the central square to commemorate the auspicious occasion.

Holders of Oklahoma Natural Gas Corporation first mortgage 6 per cent bonds, Series A, due on July 1, 1946, have been notified that the Chase National Bank, as trustee, will receive until Sept. 6 tenders for the sale to it, at prices not exceeding 104 and interest, of sufficient bonds to exhaust the sum of $356,746.

The five-story tenement house at 773 Columbus Avenue was sold yesterday by the Dry Dock Savings Institution to the Anarga Realty Corporation. The sale was negotiated by Kidder Fitzpatrick, brokers, who recently sold 771 Columbus Avenue.

PARIS, Aug. 30. -- Another heavy fall in the pound took place here today to 75.27 francs from 75.59 yesterday. At one time the British currency touched 75.12 francs, but, as the official rate is a weighted average, it always shows a higher closing than the lowest figure during the day.
LAKE CAZENOVIA, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- The nation's total public unemployment relief bill from Jan. 1, 1933, to June, 1934, was about $1,340,000,000.

The fight for supremacy in the Bronx between the Democrats under Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State for New York and leader of the Democratic organization in that borough, and the insurgent forces under John E. McCarthy, former Deputy Commissioner of Hospitals, was taken into Supreme Court yesterday amid charges of fraud and forgery and accusations of bribery.

BAD EILSEN, Germany, Aug. 30. -- During a discussion of the interplay of debt and credit problems resulting in the world depression, before today's session of the International Congress of Agrarian Economists here, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics and president of the Reichsbank, declared no other course was left to her creditors but to grant Germany a complete moratorium for a period of years.

The Senators, considerably fallen from their lordly estate of a year ago, moved into the Stadium yesterday for their final series of the year and forthwith gave added evidence to a fact no longer startling that the Cronin machine which spread-eagled the American League in 1933 has indeed come upon evil days.
NEWARK, Aug. 30. -- Newark tightened its grip on first, place in the International League today by beating Albany in both ends of a double-header. The scores were 11 to 0 and 7 to 5.

An initial dividend of $616,450 will be mailed to creditors of the Equitable Casualty and Surety Company beginning today and continuing for the next month, George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, announced yesterday. The company, which had a large bail bond business and also insured a substantial number of the city's taxicabs, has been in liquidation since Jan. 1, 1931.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Representatives of the New York carrier industry, defined as "lighterage, cement transportation, coal and dock scow groups," submitted to the NRA today a proposed code of fair competition.

A further recession in bank clearings, accounted for almost entirely in this city, was reported yesterday in Dun Bradstreet, Inc., for the last week. Clearings for the week amounted to $3,643,621,000, against $3,912,303,000 in the same week last year, a drop of 7 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP). -The job of making millions of shoes for the needy unemployed this Winter is going to be divided between private manufacturers, who will handle the bulk of it, and idle factories reopened by State relief administrations.

ALBANY, Aug. 30. -- In a proclamation setting apart Sept. 6 as Lafayette-Marne Day, Governor Lehman requested that the tri-color of France under which Lafayette fought and the Stars and Stripes be flown together on the birthday of Lafayette.
WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 30. -- John Hay (Jock) Whitney's Greentree riders defeated the Long Island polo team, 9 to 5, in a high-coal match today on Whitney Field at the Meadow Brook Club.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 30 (AP). -- Pacing the final heat in close to record time despite a strong wind on the back stretch, Dick Reynolds, owned by R.J. Reynolds of Winston-Salem, N.C., and driven by Ben White, captured the free-for-all pace, feature event on the Grand Circuit program at the Fair Grounds track today.
LONDON, Aug. 30. -- Another heavy slump today brought sterling down to 60.8 per cent of its old franc parity -- the lowest ever recorded -- and sent the price of gold soaring to a new high record.

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- A visit to Gus Wilson's training establishment led to the discovery that James Archibald McLarnin had taken to the hills. They had him hidden away in a little cottage half-way up a long slope. The pursuit party started after him.

LONDON, Aug. 30. -- The committee of managers of the London clearing banks has decided that the banks should comply with a request by the United States Treasury for returns on their incomes derived in the United States.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 30. -- Paraguay has begun a general offensive along a 145-mile front extending from Fort Ballivian to Carandayty.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Chester C. Davis, administrator, in a radio address tonight over the Columbia Broadcasting System, said that the Agricultural Adjustment Administration was preparing to conduct a referendum among corn and hog farmers to determine their wishes on the question of production control in 1935.

Applications for temporary registration under the Securities and Exchange Act have been received from only 206 of a total of 1,412 issuers whose securities are listed on the New Stock Exchange, the Exchange announced yesterday in a letter urging other companies to speed up their applications.

Striking a firm note to "resist Japan," General Tsai Ting-kai, commander of the Chinese Nineteenth Route Army which valiantly defended Shanghai against a far more powerful Japanese army early in 1932, appealed last night to the Chinese people of New York to do all in their power for Chinese independence and unity.

LONDON, Aug. 30. -- Reformers in the Salvation Army, led by Commander Evangeline Booth of the United States and Commissioner David Lamb, scored an unexpected victory in the High Council session here today when they won the right to question every nominee for the generalship before the balloting.

The total of brokers' loans, as reported by member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City in their weekly condition statement, published yesterday, fell $17,000,000 to $793,000,000. This was the eighth successive weekly decline and brought the total to the lowest level since Jan. 24, when $779,000,000 was reported.

Fearful of being caught without stocks if the threatened textile strike is prolonged, buyers have swamped the cotton mills with requests for immediate shipment of goods already ordered, selling agents reported here yesterday.

Secretary MORGENTHAU'S statement that the $2,800,000,000 "profit" from devaluation is ultimately to be used for reduction of the public debt directed attention again to the nature of that expedient. For its use by a government there is one precedent: the French Government's action after legal devaluation of the franc in 1928.

The featherweight championship of the State of New York belongs to the Republic of Mexico. The title, recently created by the New York State Athletic Commission, was assumed last night by Alberto (Baby) Arizmendi of Tampico, who easily defeated Mike Belloise, Bronx contender for the crown, in a fifteen-round bout at Dyckman Oval.

SOUTHAMTON, L.I., Aug. 30. -- A large audience attended the recital by Rafaelo Diaz, tenor of the Metropolitan Opera, and Miss Maria Serrano, coloratura soprano of the Chicago Opera Company, which was held this afternoon at the playhouse on the grounds of Three Chimneys, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Jeremiah D. Maguire.

FANOE, Denmark, Aug. 30. -- Virtually the whole Protestant world as represented on the Universal Christian Council for Life and Work went on record today with a ringing appeal for church freedom in Germany and a declaration of sympathy with the opposition pastors and their flocks.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H. Aug. 30. -- Amateur polo, horseback rides up the Thorn Mountain Trail, a revival of dances of the gay '90s and horse races for the benefit of the Memorial Hospital at North Conway were among the diversions that engaged a large group of New Yorkers at Wentworth Hall in Jackson today.

FLINT, Mich., Aug. 30. -- After defeating the Flint team, 7 to 3, before a holiday crowd of 3,000, the Giants started for home tonight to open their final drive for the National League pennant in a game at Ebbets Field with the Dodgers tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Germany's reply to Secretary of State Hull's remonstrances against her moratorium on the servicing of her foreign debt is unsatisfactory, according to official sources, in that it fails to give assurances that there will be no discrimination against American holders of Dawes and Young reparations bonds.

BUFFALO, Aug. 30. -- Enactment of a universal draft law became one of the major objectives of the New York State Department of the American Legion after addresses here today before the annual convention by Senator Royal S. Copeland and Edward H. Hayes, National Commander.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. Nelson I. Asiel gave a tea following the races yesterday for Mr. and Mrs. Seth W. Morton, Miss Adele Golgate, Mrs. Roland Wright Smith, Mrs. Phillips Allen Clark, Mrs. Forrest Hooker, Mr. and Mrs. William Ziegler Jr., Miss Christine B. McLean, Mrs. E. Vassar Baker, Mrs. Henry A. Alker and Mrs. William T. Van Alstyne.

Continuing its sharp advance, The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices rose 2.2 points during the week to 120.7 on Tuesday, the highest point in nearly four years. The advance, like last week's, was due to the rise in the prices of livestock and meats.
The total number of workers now employed in the cotton textile industry is about 300,000, almost evenly divided between the North and the South.

In the heaviest trading in a week, United States Government bonds declined 1-32 to 12-32 point on the Stock Exchange yesterday as other bonds moved generally lower. Most of the selling pressure came late in the day. The turnover in Government issues amounted to $6,651,800 of the total of $12,129,800.

BERLIN, Aug. 30. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's address before the International Congress of Agrarian Economists at Badn Eilsen today was accepted in Berlin financial circles as a logical sequel to his speech at Leipzig last Sunday.

Acting Health Commissioner William H. Best ordered yesterday a sweeping survey of the emergency milk stations at which milk is being sold to needy families at 8 cents a quart. He acted after some of the milk had been discovered in is Brooklyn bakery, the head of which was fined $25 by Magistrate Ford.

Falling death rates during the depression are declared by high medical authority not a sufficient cause for optimism. Death rates are not a "sen "sitive index of ill-health and do not "promptly measure decreased resis "tance to disease." We still have to face the full impact of depression on vitality.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 20. -- Mrs. Frank Dana Hyde and Miss Frances Dana Hyde gave a "mother and daughter" luncheon for thirty-six persons at the Devon Yacht Club today.

" Crime Without Passion," with Claude Rains and Whitney Bourne, will open at the Rialto today. It is the first production of the Ben Hecht-Charles MacArthur partnership, and was produced at the Eastern Service Studios in Astoria, L.I.

Although the policy of granting relief to needy strikers has been followed by the government for fifteen months, only about $100,000 in relief has been paid to strikers in that period, Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator, estimated yesterday.
BERLIN, Aug. 30 (AP). -- The German Postoffice announced today a spectacular plan to introduce "television telephony" in the near future.

BOSTON, Aug. 30. -- Cotton textile mills in New England will open next Tuesday morning regardless of the strike order. The owners, deciding against a lockout, will give their employes an opportunity for a test of the strength of the United Textile Workers.

LONDON, Aug. 30. -- Stocks continued strong here today, although price changes generally were small. British Government stocks advanced on further investment buying. Among the industrials, demand was more selective. Ford and Rolls-Royce were outstanding among the motors, Guinness among the breweries, and Imperial Tobacco among the tobaccos.

Judging from the speed with which New Yorkers were buying transportation elsewhere yesterday, it ought to be possible this Labor Day week-end to shoot a cannon up Fifth Avenue and hit nothing except the Murray Hill hump and some out-of-town visitors.

Overriding objections of business groups and of a small minority of its own members, the local laws committee of the Board of Aldermen voted late yesterday afternoon to report out Mayor LaGuardia's business tax bill for action at Tuesday's meeting of the board.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 30. -- The political squabble over Pennsylvania's unemployment relief problems was further enlivened today by an attack on George H. Earle, Democratic nominee for Governor, by Governor Pinchot.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Secretary Dern refused today to meet the demand of a House Military Affairs subcommittee that Major Gen. Benjamin D. Foulois be summarily dismissed as chief of the Air Corps.
Satisfaction as to the new rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission on unlisted securities was expressed yesterday by E. Burd Grubb, president of the New York Curb Exchange, who said:

Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose to about $2,000,000,000 this week when the banks added $55,000,000 to their reserve balances, it was indicated in the statistics of the Federal Reserve System for the week ended on Wednesday, published yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Dr. Smith came to St. John's Church, Washington, in 1902 from St. John's Church, Northampton, Mass. During his residence there Dr. Smith came to know intimately a young lawyer named Calvin Coolidge.

BERLIN, Aug. 30. -- German industry and the State administrative bureaus have received orders from the Reich Bureau for Labor Distribution to prepare during September for the discharge of unmarried workers who are under 25 years of age.

German women have already begun to wear Ersatz clothes made of a new material derived by chemical methods from liquefied wood. It is the first gun in the defensive battle of synthetic chemistry which the Hitler regime is set to wage against a world of enemies.

Federal Judge Murray Hulbert signed an order yesterday requiring the Loma Dress Company, Inc., 463 Seventh Avenue, to show cause why it should not be restrained from violating the provisions of the code of fair competition of the dress manufacturing industry.

In a retrenchment move deemed advisable because of the low rate of operations at its mills, the United States Steel Corporation will eliminate Saturday work for its salaried workers, effective tomorrow, and at the same time will reduce the pay of these employes about 10 per cent, it was announced yesterday. This policy will be followed at least until substantial improvement occurs in plant activities, it was said.

Representative James J. Lanzetta, running for re-election to Congress from the Twentieth Congressional District, charged yesterday in a telegram to Mayor LaGuardia that the relief activities of the Department of Public Welfare were being used in his district to further the candidacy of Vito Marcantonio, who will be his Republican rival after primary day.

Nearly 2,000,000 individuals received relief in the State during July, when $20,721,184 was expended for unemployment relief purposes, according to the regular monthly report made public yesterday by the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Wholesale commodity prices last week reached the highest level attained this year, according to Commissioner Lubin of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, in his summary issued today. It was the fourth consecutive week to show an advance.

To the standard of the New Deal so many politicians have repaired with differing objectives that President ROOSEVELT'S rule against discussing campaign matters with any State candidate is politically wise. When running for the Presidency, a man may fraternize with radicals and conservatives of all stripes, as Mr. ROOSEVELT did during the campaign of 1932, notably in the State of Washington.

A raid by Federal agents which resulted in what they termed "the biggest seizure of counterfeit liquor labels, stamps and bottle caps since repeal," was made yesterday afternoon on a room in a storage warehouse at 810 East 170th Street, the Bronx, according to the police.

Yesterday the national executive board of the United Ireland party annulled the resolution of the Blue Shirt congress that instructed the farmers not to pay annuities and the cottiers not to pay rates. Formally, then, the anticipated separation of Mr. COSCRAVE'S followers from those of General O'DUFFY is avoided.

The Brewing Corporation of Canada, Ltd., reports profits from operations for the three months ended on July 31 of $849,628, compared with $500,124 for the same period last year. Taxes increased from $375,147 in the preceding year to $618,032; miscellaneous income was higher, at $7,427, compared with $6,798, while deduction for interest was lower, at $18,804, compared with $22,896.
PARIS, Aug. 30 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission took official notice today of the railroads' petition for authority to increase existing freight rates and charges, named the case ex parte No. 115, and assigned it for hearing on Oct. 1.

BETHLEHEM, N.H., Aug. 31. -- Many Maplewood club members attended tonight "Twelfth Night" at the Maplewood Little Theatre, presented by Miss Maude Adams with a distinguished cast from the Manhattan Repertory Theatre Company.

BERLIN, Aug. 31. -- The Boerse still showed a marked tendency to weakness today as a result of Minister of Economics Hjalmar Schacht's speech yesterday amounting to an announcement of a full moratorium on the foreign debt payments.

NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Aug. 31. -- Problems of international interest to Jews, including the boycott on German goods, will be discussed at the national encampment of Jewish War Veterans, which opened here tonight.

The "Tremendous Gains Cited by Richberg in Reviewing NRA Fight on Depression" published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 27 included the statement that in June 1934, 4,120,000 more persons were employed than in March, 1933, and 2,320,000 more than in June, 1933, when the NRA came into being; also that wages had increased 37.5 per cent from June, 1933, to June, 1934.

Firmly convinced that T.O.M. Sopwith's Endeavour is the best of all the British challengers for the America's Cup, J. Stanley Lapthorn, sailmaker for the English boat, arrived in New York yesterday on the Cunarder Berengaria. Met at the pier by Ernest Ratsey, Mr. Lapthorn immediately ran into some good-natured joshing.

OREGON, Mo., Aug. 31 (AP). -- Al1 five persons aboard were killed tonight as a tri-motored Rapid Air Transport plane, bound from Kansas City to Omaha, crashed on a road near here while battling a heavy rainstorm.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- Secretary Morgenthau today announced the following amendments to existing silver regulations:

Cardinal Alexi Lepicier, Count and Countess Francesco Campello and Count and Countess Balleani Baideschi are among the passengers due to sail today for Mediterranean ports on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia. Others leaving on the ship include:

Bonds called for redemption in August before their dates of maturity exceeded those of a year ago. Only the industrial group showed a decline. The total, however, was less than half the sum for July because of a shrinkage in foreign and industrial retirements.
Most of yesterday's realty activity in Manhattan and the Bronx involved housing properties. Trading was mild as brokers and other realty interests prepared for a weekend holiday.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 31. -- With a parting shot at the New Deal, the American Bar Association, closing its annual convention here today, accepted a committee report denouncing the Securties Act of 1933 as "riding roughshod over legal principles."

The $2,000,000 Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation fifteen-year secured 6 per cent sinking fund bonds due July 1, 1949, sold to a Banking group here some weeks after the $8,000,000 issue of same bonds due June 1, 1949, have remained in the hands of the investment bankers and will not be distributed until the early part of next week.

BUFFALO, Aug. 31. -- "Take the profit out of war" and "wipe out communism in the United States" were the two challenges voiced at the annual convention of the State American Legion here today by Edward A. Hayes, national commander.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month continued to be at the slowest pace in more than a decade. Sales dropped to 164,000 shares on Saturday, Aug. 18, the smallest two hours' business since 1923. On Aug. 20 the voulme was 274,540 shares, the lowest for a day since 1922.

Attention continued to centre yesterday on the United States Government group in bond trading on the Stock Exchange as once again the turnover in the group constituted more than half the total. Sales for the day aggregated $13,367,600, of which $8,198,600 was in government securities.

With demand for funds continuing light because of dullness in the stock markets and with the seasonal lull in business, no change was made in call and time money rates in August from those in July. It was the eighth consecutive month showing the same quotation for call loans and the fifth month for time accommodations.

Fifty-four members of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company from the Savoy Theatre, London, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria, and were met at the pier by the business manager, Richard Collet, who came last week to make arrangements at the Martin Beck Theatre, where their Gilbert and Sullivan season will commence on Monday night.

The corner of Broad and Wall Streets, home of the Stock Exchange and of J.P. Morgan Co., was thrown into confusion by a jokester's "bomb" shortly after the close of trading yesterday. First there was a dull explosion. Then a thick cloud of black smoke curled up over the facade of the Exchange.

PARIS, Aug. 31. -- As in all European markets today securities on the Paris Bourse fell sharply in the reaction to Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's demand for a full moratorium on German debts. France would not lose much from such a moratorium because her bankers and industrialists always were careful to have as little a stake as possible in Germany, but that did not save Paris from the indirect effects of the Reichsbank President's address.

All that Wall Street took notice of particularly in yesterday's boggy market was that trading was still under restraint. The trading was of insignificant proportions and the price movements were unimportant. Speculators looked at the market with a skeptical eye and concluded not to do anything, as the final quotation plainly showed.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- Plans for the refinancing and exchange of about $1,725,000,000 of Federal obligations, due in the next few weeks, will be announced Sept. 10, it was stated officially today after President Roosevelt went over the government's fiscal program with Secretary Morgenthau and other Treasury officials.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- The Agricultural Adjustment Administration today accepted the offer of Commissioner Charles H. Baldwin of the New York Department of Agriculture and Markets to renew negotiations looking to a joint State-Federal plan of regulation for the New York-New Jersey milk market.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31. -- With a holiday ahead the demand for hogs today was not active and prices were steady to 15 cents a hundredweight lower than yesterday. Packing sows showed the greatest loss. Strong weight light hogs and butchers generally sold 5 to 10 cents lower while light lights were about steady.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31. -- Traders in grains on the Board of Trade were somewhat disappointed because the private crop estimates, issued today, failed to show well below general expectations and, as frequently is the case when bullish news is received, the markets declined, with profit-taking the main factor.

LONDON, Aug. 31. -- British Government stocks continued to make headway today, although sterling tumbled to a new low record and the price of gold shot upward to 140s 11 1/2d an ounce, a new high price. German bonds slumped heavily on the latest pronouncement by Minister of Economics Hjalmar Schacht.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31. -- American industry has seen the "age of unlimited competition" come to an end and now needs a spirit of "cooperation rather than conflict," according to a Labor Day message issued today for the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. by the Rev. Dr. John McDowell of New York.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- More than $1,000,000 worth of new Westchester highway improvements built during the Summer with Federal and State funds will be available for Labor Day use by motorists, although none of the projects has been finished, it was announced today.

In August bank loans other than security loans, which presumably represent largely commercial borrowing, showed their first substantial increase since the Autumn of 1933, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reports in its monthly review, issued yesterday.
LONDON, Aug. 31. -- The High Council of the Salvation Army performed an astonishing about-face today when it suddenly undid all the work its reformers had accomplished yesterday.

ALBANY, Aug. 31. -- Governor Lehman today attached his first veto to a bill passed at the extraordinary session when he disapproved the Fearon-Ross measure which was designed to protect the name or emblem of an independent body on election ballots.

Albert Goldman, Commissioner of Plant and Structures under Mayor Walker, will take office today as Acting Postmaster of New York City, succeeding John J. Kiely, who will be retained as assistant postmaster at his own request.
GENEVA, Aug. 31 (AP). -- League of Nations officials here tonight credited Great Britain's support of Russian membership to her apprehension over political tension in the Far East.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

August, which in Wall Street is considered the last month of Summer in spite of all calendar rules, closed yesterday with the share market almost at a standstill and with bonds and commodities departing only slightly from the price levels of the previous day. With the exception of one or two of the agricultural staples, there were no changes of consequence.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31. -- Eighty-thousand persons saw the Collegian All-Stars of 1933 and the Chicago Bears, champions of professional football, battle to a scoreless tie under the arc lights of Soldier Field tonight.

GREENVILLE, S. C., Aug. 31. -- With union leaders determined to make an impressive showing, and confidence on the part of mill owners in their own ability to control the situation, preparations were being speeded today by both sides in this area for the opening of the great industrial battle in the cotton textile industry, set by the United Textile Workers for shortly before midnight tomorrow.

LONDON, Aug. 31 (Canadian Press). -- The first class county cricket season came to an end today, with Lancashire the champion county. Yorkshire, champion for three years, trailed by a considerable margin at the end of the thirty-match schedule.

Suspension of Germany's private debt payments, which began as a "six months moratorium," is apparently now to be extended indefinitely. Dr. SCHACHT continues to attempt to throw all the blame for Germany's failure to pay upon her creditors. The ideal solution of the whole problem, it appears, would be for all the nations of the world to admit German goods completely free of duty, and then cancel the German debts entirely.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP). -- Dizzy Dean conquered his season's jinx today to score his twenty-third victory of the campaign and pitch the Cardinals into a tie with the Cubs for second place in the National League standing. Largely because of Dean's pitching, the Cards won the opener of the series, 3 to 1.

BERLIN, Aug. 31. -- Although the Soviet-American debt negotiations apparently are "making progress backward," it would be unreasonable, or at least premature, to suppose that hope of a settlement must be definitely abandoned.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP). -- Art intention by the Federal Reserve Board to supervise with microscopic minuteness the margin operations of brokers and stock traders was revealed today in a copy of the board's preliminary draft of regulations.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 31. -- Fifteen thousand silk workers in the Passaic Valley are ready to go on strike, according to officials of local unions affiliated with the American Federation of Silk Workers. They reported that they had organized machinery for a general walkout and that mass meetings had been arranged.

PARIS, Aug. 31. -- Le Bourget, the huge Paris airfield, was "destroyed" by an "attacking" force today for the second time in forty-eight hours, and the press interprets this theoretical disaster as proof that even a powerful air force cannot be relied on to repel an actual invader.

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., Aug. 31. -- At the concert given this evening by students of Mme. Marcella Sembrich for the benefit of the Episcopal Church of St. Sacrament at Bolton Landing, Lake George, Lucretia Bori and Cornelius Bliss of New York City were guests of honor.
LONDON, Aug. 31. -- With sterling weakening afresh to new low records in terms of the gold currencies, the pound fell today below $5 for the first time since last February.

The man who was the prime factor in the creation of the new cup defender, Rainbow, who watched her through early disappointments and nursed her through to the defense berth is Harold S. Vanderbilt, racing skipper and bridge player extraordinary.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31. -- Orders to proceed at once with preparations for a walkout of all cotton garment workers who are members of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union were received here today by Morris Bialis, vice president of the union.
LONDON, Aug. 31 (AP). -- Great Britain does not fear her new advocacy of Russian membership in the League of Nations will endanger her traditional friendship with Japan.

An appraisal yesterday of the estate of Charles E.F. Clarke, who was president of the Pennsylvania Water and Power Company and was an officer of other corporations, showed that while he left gross assets worth $698,839, he had debts of $807,842, and was insolvent.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Aug. 31. -- Southern textile manufacturers stood aloof tonight from the rapidly forming strike front, while a definite cleavage made itself felt among the employes themselves.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- Announcement by the NRA today that the infants' and children's wear industry has approved a reduction of work hours from 40 to 36, accompanied by a 10 per cent increase in hourly wage rates, revealed that there are now thirteen codes, covering more than 1,000,000 workers, operating under a 35, 36 or 37 1/2 hour week.

Freddy Fitzsimmons once again showed his mastery over the Dodgers yesterday at Ebbets Field. In overpowering Casey Stengel's athletes for the fifth time this season, the Giants' chubby knuckleball expert scattered five hits among them and might have registered a shutout save for a wild throw by Gus Mancuso.

Polo fans turn with interest today to the first really severe game which the Western invaders have played since their arrival on Long Island and to their first appearance as a team. At 4 o'clock, on Hitchcock Field of the Meadow Brook Club, the four men expected to start for the West against the East a week from today will ride out against international opposition that includes in its line-up strength and team work.

For many metropolitan anglers Labor Day week-end brings the climax of the fishing season. Each year thousands hie themselves to familiar rendezvous for one last fling at their favorite sport. In row boats, charter craft and open vessels, salt water devotees concentrate on the various fishing grounds.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 31. -- After the announcement of the selection of Rainbow as defender of the America's Cup, Harold S. Vanderbilt, her skipper and manager, invited the members of her after-guard along with several of those who helped in her construction and rigging to dinner tonight on board his motor yacht Vara at anchor in the harbor.

Dame Sybil Thorndike, noted English actress-manager, arrived yesterday from London on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria to be the star in the John Van Druten play, "The Distaff Side," which is the history, in three acts, of a family of three generations.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31 (AP). -- The Browns took the opening game of the series from the White Sox today, 3 to 2, with an eleventh inning rally.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 31. -- Isaac K. Merrill of Daytona, Fla., medalist in the thirty-eighth annual invitation tournament at the Stockbridge Golf Club, will oppose Henry Cordes of the Greenock Country Club in the final tomorrow.

Bringing down the Senators was a little tighter fit yesterday than it had been for the Yanks in the opening clash of the series at the Stadium. But in the end the McCarthy forces again had their way about it and so recorded their second straight victory over the fading American League champions, 3 to 1.

The present situation of railroad properties, with reference to the appeals made to the Interstate Commerce Commission for an increase of income by raising rates, brings to the front the question to whom the railroads really belong.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- The automobile industry has asked and received a temporary extension of its code for sixty days, it was learned in authoritative quarters today. Official announcement of this action was not made because of the absence of General Johnson at Bethany Beach, Del.

One of the most colorful national tennis championships since the days of Bill Tilden, Vincent Richards and Bill Johnston starts today at Forest Hills. The field of 164 entrants includes, with one exception, the holders of the most important tennis titles in the world.

Owing to the heavy drains which free hospitalization for the indigent has made upon the resources of Flower Hospital it is imperative that income from contributions be increased. During the past few years it has been necessary to draw heavily upon unrestricted capital funds.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has agreed to lend the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad $4,750,000 to enable it to reorganize, F.J. Lisman, a member of the reorganization committee, announced yesterday. The committee, which decided to ask the court to adjourn for sixty days the sale of the property, set for Wednesday, appointed Mr. Lisman, W.W. Colpitts and Philip J. Roosevelt a subcommittee to further the reorganization.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- ''The Nightmare of 1934," a painting satirizing President Roosevelt and the New Deal, which had been on exhibition here since last Tuesday in the galleries of the Westchester Institute of Fine Arts, was damaged beyond repair today by an alien house painter.

The excitement prevailing in various cotton mill centres throughout the country yesterday was reflected in the local selling market only in the insistent demands of buyers that their goods previously ordered be shipped out immediately.

A formal call to the twenty-first annual national foreign trade convention to be held here Oct. 31, and Nov. 1 and 2, was sent to exporters and importers yesterday by James A. Farrell, chairman of the National Foreign Trade Council. According to estimates by officials of the council yesterday, the meeting, which will be held at the Hotel Commodore, will attract about 1,500 foreign traders from all parts of the country.

Benjamin Franklin Varn, who sent a letter to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt threatening harm to the President and their grandchildren unless she paid him $168,000, was sent to Bellevue Hospital yesterday for mental observation.

HAVANA, Aug. 31. -- Three men with machine guns invaded the Correctional Court here today and fled with Rodolfo Rodriguez Fernandez as he was about to be arraigned in connection with a machine-gun attack on an ABC parade on June 17, in which twelve persons were killed and sixty wounded.

MACON, Ga., Aug. 31. -- The Macon mill district enacted a disorderly prelude to the general strike called for Saturday night by the United Textile Workers, and then closed all plants today for the Labor Day holiday. More than a score of strikers were arrested and several minor casualties were reported.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 31. -- Rainbow, the America's Cup yacht sailed and managed by Harold S. Vanderbilt, tonight was chosen defender of the America's Cup to meet T.O.M. Sopwith's challenger Endeavour from the Royal Yacht Squadron of Cowes, England.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- Seventeen of the best 2-year-olds in training will go to the post for tomorrow's $25,000 Hopeful Stakes, richest race of the meeting and big feature of getaway day.

WHITEFIELD, N.H., Aug. 31. -- With a foretaste of superb Autumn weather, the Forty Niners from Yale University School of Drama revived "Rip Van Winkle" for their eighth final production in the Chase Barn Playhouse here tonight. Their season will end with the same work on Labor Day, after entertaining some 4,000 tourists and earning the good-will of Whitefield village and the White Mountain countryside.

PARIS, Aug. 31. -- It is considered here that the speech of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, German Minister of Economics, gave Continental speculators who have been playing the pound short a new weapon today whereof they made telling use. According to French estimates, the British still have about 700,000,000 gold marks of frozen debts in Germany.
The Triborough Bridge Authority announced yesterday that Public Works Administrator Ickes had approved the inclusion of an East River marginal parkway in the Triborough Bridge project.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP). -- Important new finds of skeletons and other relics of prehistoric races which once lived on Kodiak Island, Alaska, were reported today to the Smithsonian Institution by Dr. Ales Hrdlicka.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 31. -- Mrs. Charles E. Van Vleck Jr. gave a supper dance tonight at Ballyshear, her home in the Shinnecock Hills. The gardens and terraces were brilliantly illuminated by flood lights, simulating moonlight.

The new novel by Ellen Glasgow is to be published by Harcourt, Brace Co., instead of Doubleday, Doran, it was learned yesterday. The book will be a departure for Miss Glasgow in that, where her novels have heretofore dealt with the tidewater region of Virginia, this new one takes for a setting the basin of the James River, between the Blue Ridge and the Alleghanies, and covers the period from 1901 to 1933.

LONDON, Aug. 31 (AP). -- British labor declared war today on fascism and Nazism. A manifesto issued by the general council of the Trades Union Congress threw the whole weight of British organized labor into the fight.

The British Foreign Secretary has suggested to our Government and to several others an exchange of views on the question of restricting ocean tonnage. The proposal is regarded in Washington as of special interest because it comes at a time when the Postoffice Department is about to hold hearings on the question of ocean mail contracts which provide indirect subsidies for American shipping.

Dividends declared in August showed only greater aggregate payment than a year ago, but a marked rise in extra disbursements over the previous month and over August, 1933. There were also numerous payments of dividends that had been in arrears, particularly on cumulative preferred stocks.

SHEBOYGAN, Wis., Aug. 31. -- Representatives of the American Federation of Labor withdrew tonight from the hearing held here by the National Labor Relations Board in connection with the strike at the Kohler Manufacturing Company.

A small brown macaque monkey caused hundreds of office boys and stenographers to overstay their luncheon period, taxed the patience and ingenuity of a special squad of policemen and afforded a novel spectacle to a large crowd that gathered at Vesey and Church Streets yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- With the relief situation presenting what Harry L. Hopkins, FERA Administrator, characterized last week as a "fairly constant problem," indications are that relief funds now on hand will be exhausted on or before the middle of January.

The plan for relieving the wholesale gasoline markets from pressure of "distress" material is reported in the trade as having been approved by Secretary Ickes of the Interior Department. The major oil companies are to buy quantities of "distress" gasoline east of the Rocky Mountains with the object of stabilizing conditions.
The letter by Mrs. Mary Chalmers Hood about the TVA in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 21 seems to be of rather doubtful accuracy in certain respects and of questionable timeliness in others.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 31 (AP). -- The fastest mile trotted by a juvenile this year was turned in today by Greyhound, fleet Juvenile owned by E.J. Baker, St. Charles, Ill., as he circled the State Fair oval in 2:05 1/2 to win the second heat of the $1,000 purse for 2-year-olds featuring the closing day's Grand Circuit program.

Issues of notes offered By the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and the city of Boston and aggregating $9,000,000 were awarded yesterday to banking groups headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. The Massachusetts issue, consisting of $6,000,000 of one-year obligations, dated Sept. 7, was bought at a rate of 0.55 per cent plus a premium of $101.

The danger of a city-wide trucking strike which had threatened to tie up industry and hamper the movement of the food supply was averted yesterday evening as a result of all-day mediation by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick and Ben Golden, vice chairman and executive secretary of the Regional Labor Board.

Harry L. Hopkins, Federal relief administrator, served notice yesterday upon Governor Gifford Pinchot, following the apparent deadlocking of a conference at the Hotel Waldorf Astoria, that the State of Pennsylvania faced an unemployment relief crisis.

Two women crossing Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, at streets two blocks apart, were struck and knocked down by the same automobile last midnight. Both were injured critically. The driver continued on until his car was halted and he was saved from a menacing crowd by the police.

Officials of the Code Authority for the pleating, stitching, bonnaz and hand embroidery industry were accused in the Supreme Court yesterday of malicious prosecution of Caesar Capozzi, crochet beading manufacturer of 1,369 Sixty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, by falsely accusing him of underpaying his employes.

LONDON, Aug. 31. -- Londoners were startled the other day at the sight of an autogyro plane hovering so low over Trafalgar Square that the craft looked as if it might hit the Nelson Monument. Aboard the autogyro were police officials studying the problem of controlling from the air London's ever-increasing traffic congestion.

LONDON, Aug. 31 (AP). -- The "big four" wheat nations abandoned tonight further efforts to reduce acreage next year. Argentina, Australia, Canada and the United States merely agreed to maintain in effect acreage reductions made last year.

The Democratic forces under the leadership of Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State and county leader in the Bronx, registered another victory yesterday when the Board of Elections struck from the primary ballot additional names of county committee designees sponsored by John E. McCarthy, former Deputy Commissioner of Hospitals, leader of the Bronx insurgent group.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 31. -- Bandits today kidnapped two Americans, six Japanese and one Chinese, after wrecking the express train on which they were riding from Harbin to Hsinking, the capital of Manchukuo. The wreck occurred twenty-six miles south of Harbin.
